author: hndrewaall
content: does this mean that CLs will have to stop accepting lists of ELs to talk to? just thinking of how today with lighthouse i can point the beacon client at multiple geth instances for redundancy

author: ajsutton
content: The CL can drive multiple ELs but it will have to be a hot/hot setup where all the ELs are sent pretty much all the requests since that's how they stay in sync with the chain.

author: ajsutton
content: But if one was offline or syncing the responses from the other could still be used, so you get redundancy.  Not sure if anyone has implemented this yet so it's still a bit theoretical.

author: hndrewaall
content: so that does still place some new topological restrictions: today i think we can have one validator pointed at two beacon nodes each pointed at two shared geth clients. post merge id need two geth instances per beacon node. am i getting that right?

author: hndrewaall
content: maybe the geth instances could at least fail over between the two?

author: ajsutton
content: You can't share EL nodes between BN nodes.  But you don't need two ELs per BN to get redundancy if the VC is switching between the two BNs.

author: ajsutton
content: So VC splitting between two BN<->EL pairs would give redundancy.

author: hndrewaall
content: right, just a little bit less (unless we can have them fail over)

author: ajsutton
content: 2 ELs to the beacon nodes just leaves you with the weakest point being 2 BNs. So not really sure it adds much extra benefit.

author: ajsutton
content: But I think we're getting way off topic for this channel. ðŸ™‚

author: jlokier
content: Fwiw it is possible to share EL node resources among multiple CL nodes with some technical modifications to the EL node.

author: jlokier
content: It's not clear that it's worth the engineering effort, because single-CL stakers don't need it, and anyone institutional with multiple CL stakes likely has enough resources to run multiple independent ELs anyway.

author: jlokier
content: But I'm looking at the economics and engineering aspects of building a multi-CL capable EL if anyone's interested.
